div.head: The HISTORY of the Black Prince, &c.
CHP. I.

argument.p: How the French King, upon King Edward the Thirds coming to the Crown, ≈øent to him to come to Paris, and do him homage, for the Pallaces the Engli≈øh held in France; how he not only refu≈øed it, but layd claim to the Crown of France, Quartered their Arms with his own; entered into confederacy with the Neighbouring Princes, Invaded them with powerful Armys, his love to the Counte≈øs of Salisbury, the order of the Garter, &c.

div.p: WHEN the Engli≈øh valour was famous, and more Renowned, than that of other Nations, our Warlike heroes contended more for fame than Gold, and brought a terror on their Enemys, wherever they carryed their Arm; proud France then trembled, and the Engli≈øh Lyon gra≈øped, with ≈øo ≈øtrong a hand, their Golden Lillys, that all the ≈øtruggling of that large Kingdom was not able to re≈øcue them from the ≈øpoil, and becoming the trophies of out Conquering Princes, as I ≈øhall plainly and largely ≈øhow you in this Famous Hi≈øtory.

King Edward the third in his Fathers life-time took upon him the Title of king of England, by the con≈øent of the three E≈øtates a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, when he was but Fifteen Years of Age, and Young as he was, ≈øhewed much of a Martial ≈øpirit, and promi≈øed great things to the world, which he accordingly performed, for having Warred ≈øucce≈øsfully in Scotland, and brought that to his terms, their king ≈øubmitting and holding fealtie of him, he making and unmaking them at plea≈øure: Phillip D' Valois The French king, began to mi≈øtru≈øt his growing greatne≈øs, and thinking whil≈øt he was young, to put a Check to his forward Valour, ≈øent to demand his Homage, for the Province of Guyen, held by him in the kingdom of France; but he not only ‚Ä¢ outly refu≈øed it, in the terms the French Required it, by the Advice of his Peers, lay'd claim to the Crown of
France, as coming to him in the right of Queen I≈øabel his mother, bein his due both by civil Law, and order of Succe≈ø≈øion, as being Nephew to Charles the Fourth, Brother to the ≈øaid I≈øabel; and that as much as Phillip then Reigning, was de≈øcended of a ≈øecond Branch; to this the French oppo≈øed their Sal≈øque Law, wherein it was provided, that no Woman ≈øhould inherit the Crown of France; but this being looked on as contrived to hinder the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of the Engli≈øh kings in their Marriages, with the Daughters of France, and king Edward declaring, he was a Male of a Female that had right to the Crown, that pretence ought not to Exclude him; a War upon the≈øe grounds was Proclaimed, the king quartering the Arms of France with tho≈øe of England, and laying a Peremptorie claime to the Crown.

This Bu≈øine≈øs as it was extraordinary weighty, ≈øo it required much ≈øecrecy, untill it was well layed; for which purpo≈øe king Edward craved the Advice of the Earl of Hanault, Father to Phillipa his Queen, and Mother to Edward the Black Prince, who was growing up to great Actions, as will hereafter appear; who with his Brother, and other Nobles of Flanders, procured king Edward to be created Vicar General of the Empire: that ≈øo without being controuled, he might command the Nobles, and common people of tho≈øe Countrys, to further his purpo≈øe in the intended War.

But how private ≈øoever the≈øe things were carried, Phillip, the French king had private notice of what was doing, and ≈øtopped the huge Army he ‚Ä¢ ad rai≈øed, at the Importunity of Pope Benedict, the Eleventh, from pa≈ø≈øing into the Holy Land, to war again≈øt the Turks and Sarazens, who there mightily oppre≈ø≈øed the Chri≈øtians, Re≈øolving to defend his own Country from the threatened ≈øtorm.

In the mean while king Edward rai≈øed great Sums of Mony, and Leabyed men, and with his Queen Sailed into Flanders, where that Winter they remained at Antwerp, and Conferrnig with the Princes and States of Germany, he ≈øo well ≈øettled his Affairs, that in the Spring, he Landed in France, with an Army con≈øi≈øting of 27000 Fighting-men, bringing a great terror on the Country, though the French king had on Army of 60000 Common Souldiers to oppo≈øe him, being accompanied with Three kings, viz. of Bohemia, Scotland, and Navarre, Five Dukes, Six and Twenty Earls, and more than Four Thou≈øond Lords, and knights; and ≈øo both Armys drawing into the Field, and approaching each other, as the bloody bla≈øt was about to be ≈øounded, by the Mediation of Jane, Counte≈øs of Hanault, Si≈øter to king Phillip, and Mother to king Edward's Queen, they ≈øeperated from each other, without ≈øtriking a
blow, to the great di≈øcontent of the Engli≈øh, who full of Valour thir≈øted to begin the Battle on the fir≈øt command.

King Edward however laid not a≈øide his pretentions, but hearing the French king had ≈øet out a great Fleet, con≈øi≈øting of 200 Sail of his own, and other Nations, he had hired, which had on Board them 40000 men, who Robbed the Engli≈øh Merchants, and made ≈øome ≈øpoils on our Coa≈øt, being full of Magnanimity and Valour, Re≈øolute in his purpo≈øes, and reckoning the French as his Subjects, and Inferiours in Arms; E≈øpecially on the Seas, and hoping by his good ≈øucce≈øs, not only to win Honour among the Princes, and Sates of his confederacy, and purpo≈øing if he might to ≈øtrike Terror in the French Nation, concerning tho≈øe Wars, ≈øet upon their whole Navy, with ≈øuch incomparable courage, and bold ≈øpirit; that after a long, Ob≈øtinate and Bloody Fight, very few or none of the French Ships e≈øcaped; but were either taken, ≈øunk, or burnt by the Engli≈øh, with a much Inferiour Number, with incon≈øiderable lo≈øs on our ≈øide: This great Sea Victory much di≈øcouraged the French, and mightily encouraged the Engli≈øh, and their Confederates, ≈øo that the king landing at Slace in Triumph and going from thence to Gaunt, where his Queen lay, and the Black Prince was accompanied with Seven Earls, Eight Bi≈øhops, Twenty eight Barrons, Two Hundred knights, 4000 Men at Arms, and ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ e Thou≈øand Archers; all Valiant Engli≈øh-Men, he joyned the Duke of Brabant, who commanded 22000 men, Jaques Dartwell a famous Fleming, who commanded 60000 men of the≈øe Provinces, al≈øo the Duke of Guilder, the Marque≈øs of Meu≈øe, the Earls of Juliers, Mons, Savens, and Hanault, the Lord Tralquemont, and divers others.

With this gallant Army he Be≈øieged the Strong City of Tournay, which was with great Re≈øolutiou and Valour Manfully defended, for the ≈øpace of ten weeks; in all which time, the French king appeared not to Relieve it; however, by the Mediation of the aforementioned Jane De' Valois, Mother to the Queen of England, and to the Dutches of Juliers, to the then Earl of Hanault, and Si≈øter to the French king, a Truce was once more concluded; but that expired, ≈øoon after the≈øe delays the War begun in earne≈øt.

During the≈øe tran≈øactions, the king returned home to beat the Scots out of England, who; in his ab≈øence, dared to Invade it, under the Leading of David their king, fell de≈øperately in Love with the Fair Counte≈øs of Salisbury; in this manner having delivered her from the Siege layed to her Ca≈øtle of Roxbourough, hard pre≈ø≈øed by the Scots, he di≈øarmed him≈øelf and with ten or twelve Lords and knights, entered the Ca≈øtle, where the excellent Beauty, and mode≈øt behaviour of the ≈øweet Counte≈øs, ≈øo Inflamed
his heart, that by ≈øecret and Amorous wooing, he endeavoured to per≈øwade her to ea≈øe his pa≈ø≈øion, with a return of her Love; but the Virtuous Lady, fir≈øt with mild and kind entreatys, and afterward with quick and nipping Reprehen≈øions, ≈øtrove to make him ≈øee his own Error; but ≈øuch was his de≈øire, and her denyal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ were ≈øo peremptorie, and re≈øolute, that Di≈øcontentedly at that time he left her; yet love ≈øtill prevailing, he wrote the following Letter to her.

body.head: The King's Letter to the Counte≈øs of Salisbury.
body.p: Your Eyes have enthralled my heart, and A mid≈øt the Alarums of War, my thoughts are chained to your Beautys, and other rare perfections; take compa≈ø≈øion on a King, which nothing on Earth, but your Peerle≈øs ≈øelf, can bring to the low ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of a ≈øupplicant; I own your Virtues are great, yet to ≈øave the life of a Monarch, what ≈øhould not one, who is all Goodne≈øs, and tenderly made for Compa≈ø≈øion, like you, do? Let me entreat you then to take Compa≈ø≈øion on the ≈øufferings of my labouring mind, that I may be re≈øtored to my former peace and tranquility; & become plea≈øent to my friends, and as I have been wont, a terror to the enemy of my Country: So in expectation you will Relent, and become mild and merciful, I re≈øt in hopes of enjoying that ble≈ø≈øing, I ≈øo earne≈øtly wi≈øh for, and pa≈ø≈øionately de≈øire;

closer.signed: Your devout Lover though a King.

div.p: The vertuous Counte≈øs having well weighed the Contents of this Letter, was much troubled in her mind, her blu≈øhes came and went; ≈øhe well knew the King was already married to a Fair and Virtuous Prince≈øs; & that he ≈øought by unlawful Love to defile her bed; this ≈øome times put her unto a grievous pa≈ø≈øion, and then relenting, Pearly tears trickled from her Eyes, con≈øidering if ≈øhe yielded, how much it would turn to her di≈øhonour; and if ≈øhe refu≈øed, how much ≈øhe mu≈øt trouble and afflict the brave≈øt Prince on Earth; at other times, ≈øhe con≈øidered, ≈øhe was his Subject, and in his power, and knew not to what force his wild pa≈ø≈øion might carry him; yet tender and careful of her cha≈øttiy and honour; in the end ≈øhe returned him this an≈øwer.

body.head: The COUNTESSES An≈øwer.
body.p:
COuld you but conceive what trouble and di≈øturbance Your Letter has wrought in my mind, you would cea≈øe to afflict me, who ≈øo highly Honour you in all Virtuous ways; but in this matter, without a violation of my Honour, cannot Conde≈øcend to plea≈øure you; Con≈øider you are Marryed to a Cha≈øt and Virtuous Queen, who Loves and Honours you; how then can you ≈øtray from the Rules of that virtue, you have ever Exerci≈øed,
and Encouraged in others; to harbour thoughts in your Royal Brea≈øt, of wronging her Bed? Cea≈øe then, great Sir, to per≈øecute me with your Love, that cannot be Lawfully returned; lay a≈øide your pa≈ø≈øion, and be again your ≈øelf: I am indeed your ≈øubject, and you may indeed command my life and fortunes, but not in a Di≈øhonourable way, the ≈øpotting my innocency, and Cha≈øtity, the fir≈øt of whic ‚Ä¢
I will always be ready to ≈øacrifice, to the pre≈øervation of the Latter: So humbly Entreating you to con≈øider and weigh the≈øe things; I remain your much afflicted Subject and Servant.

div.p: The King upon Receipt of this Letter was not a little Aba≈øhed, tormenting him≈øelf for a time, thus to be Repul≈øed; but ca≈øting many things in his mind, at length he Concluded, time, and Rich pre≈øents, might overcome her Womani≈øh fears and ≈øcruples, rendering her more tractable; and in this bu≈øine≈øs, he tru≈øted his faithful Confident, the Lo ‚Ä¢ d Montaone, Brother in Law to the Counte≈øs, who Ignorant of the King's main intentions, ≈øo ≈øolicited his Fair Si≈øter, that he brought her to Court, in Honour of who≈øe pre≈øence, the King cau≈øed Magnificent Sports and Pa≈øtimes; and at la≈øt won ≈øo much upon her as to dance with him; when in the end of the Dance a Blew Ribbon, which ≈øhe had for her Garter, falling off; the King ≈øtooped, and took it up; at which the Counte≈øs blu≈øhed, and the Nobles ≈ømiled, whereat the King ≈øaid, Honi Soit Qui Male Pan≈øe; evil be to him that evil thinketh: Vowing, that e'er long, the greate≈øt of them, ≈øhould do Honour to that ≈øilken tye, and having Created his Son Edward, the Black Prince (≈øo called from his terrible deeds in War) Prince of Wales, he E≈øtabli≈øhed the Order of the Garter, Confining the number to 26 of which him≈øelf, and his Succe≈ø≈øors were Soveraigns, which Order is Yearly Solemnized, with Princely Magnificence in the Kings Ca≈øtle at Wind≈øor.

But now to pa≈øs from Love again to Arms, we find the Drums rattling, and the Trumpets ≈øounding to War; great Armys prepared on either ≈øide, and the Earl of Darby Landed with the King's Forces in Ga≈øcoin, where they drove the French Army before them, and took many Citys, Towns and Ca≈øtles, ≈øubduing almo≈øt all that large Province in ≈ømall time.
But now come I to ≈øpeak of the black Prince, that honour of virtue, and Valour, more particularly than I have done.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: The Birth of the Renowned and Victorious Black, what progedies and wonders then happened, pre≈øaning his greatne≈øs; His forward valour and activity in his young days; His fir≈øt wars under his Father in France; and the great advantages that en≈øued; How King Edward Challenged the French King, and on what account he refu≈øed it; with other matters.

div.p: PRince Edward Sirnaned (for his Valorous Actions, ≈øo much ≈øpoken of throughout the world) the Black Prince, was born at Greenwich, the 14th of May 1336, being the Elde≈øt Son of King Edward the Third, and His beautious Queen Phillip ‚Ä¢ , Daughter to the Carl of Hanault; at his birth a blazing Star appeared with a fiery tail, like a bloody Sword, pointing towards France, at South Ea≈øt; and bringing a terror upon the world; the Sea overflowed its banks in many places, and retiring again, left ≈øtrange Mon≈øterous Fifth on the Shore, the like never having, b√©en ≈øeen on our coa≈øt; In Devon≈øhire, Armys were ≈øeen Fighting in the Air, with great bla≈øts of Thunder and Lightening; that which came from the North vanqui≈øhing & pur≈øuing the Southern Army, till it was clear out of ≈øight; then the skys o'reca≈øt, and became as red as blood, red Glares of Lightening frequently breaking out, to the threatening a di≈øtruction of tho≈øe that were near Inhabitants:

The≈øe ≈øtrange p ‚Ä¢ ogidies, made people look for ≈øome wonderful Event of things, and indeed they happened ≈øoon after in a cruel war between two mighty Nations, in which this Prince (now born) was to „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øo great a part.

The King his Father though as yet he was his only Son, brought him not up nicely and tenderly; but as ≈øoon as he had, in a manner, pa≈ø≈øed his Sawdling-cleaths, enured him to hard≈øhips, in Kiding, Travelling on foot, Running, Shooting in the long bow, Managing the great Hor≈øe, running Carrears, Leaping, and in the u≈øe of the Sword; in all which he became very Expert and Dexterous, Training up many Children under him, as his Souldiers, when he was very young; and the≈øe he took great Delight to exerci≈øe, making them expert in the trains of War: So that growing up with him, he preferred them to Commands, many of which became brave Souldiers, and great Commanders, doing wonderous feats in Arms, to the Terror of their Ensmys, their own Fame, and the Honour of their Country.

He was ≈øcarce Fifteen years Old when the King his Father took him to the Wars, both again≈øt Scotland, and France; and Jaques Dartwell the great General of the Flemings, was ≈øo taken with his monly a≈øpect, & promi≈øing virtues, that he laboured to depo≈øe Loys Earl of Flanders, as
laizey cowardly, and unfit for Government, and place the Prince over tho≈øe Provinces; and thus he propo≈øed to the Nobles in their A≈ø≈øembly, with ≈øo much earne≈øtne≈øs, Magnifying the young Prince's Early Valour, and promi≈øing virtues to that degree, that though he was all in all with them before he ≈øo far incouraged their hatred, that they incen≈øed the common people again≈øt him, as one that intended to betray the liberty of his Country to ≈øtrangers, which took ≈øo effectually with tho≈øe that had adored him a little before, that he no ≈øooner came home to his hou≈øe at Gaunt, but it was be≈øt by the Multitude, when comming ont to appra≈øe them, they in a populer fury Murthered him; and this for a time much hindered King Edward's affairs; for the flemnigs and others revolted from him; but he did not greatly regard it, re≈øolving to pur≈øue his right, and by his own power thru≈øt his Sword into the bowels of France.

The King being now informed, that John the Elde≈øt Son of the French King had Be≈øieged the Ca≈øtle of Auguillion, in Ga≈øcoine, he took the Prince with him, and a con≈øiderable Army, at the terror of who≈øe approach, the French rai≈øed the Siege, and fled: After this he pa≈ø≈øed into Normandy, took the rich City of Harefl ‚Ä¢ re without Re≈øi≈øtance, and be≈øtowed the ≈øpoil on his Souldiers; after this he ≈øpoiled the Rich Towns of Cheriborough, Mount-borough Quarentive, and the Ca≈øtle there; and increa≈øing his Army, took the great and Rich City of Cane in Normandy; in which were the Earls of Tankervile, Ewe, and Guyers, who had brought Forces thither; the≈øe were made pri≈øoners to Sir Thomas Holland, an Engli≈øh Knight, with one Eye, who ≈øold them to the King; and they (with the Rich Spoils) were ≈øent Pri≈øoners to England: Then the Army marching to Lowers, quickly won it, s aal≈øo Gilors vernor, St. Germains Enley, Mountrell St. Cloudy Rely, and the whole Country about Roan, Pout, De Larch, Nauts, Newlench, Robois Fountain, Polis Vinne; & in all the places he found but weak Re≈øi≈øtance, of which Phillip, the French King, having intelligence; and that King Edward with his whole Army was within two Leagues of Paris, he fearfully left that City, and went to St. Denis, where his Army lay, per≈øwading the Pari≈øions, that the Engli≈øh dared not to look them in the Face, but their fears made them not Credit it, e≈øpecially when they heard the Lord Harecourt, King Edward's Mar≈øhall, had routed the Forces that were coming from Ancidus, to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, killing, and taking mo≈øt of them Pri≈øoners.

The Engli≈øh Army, under the King, and Black Prince, being thus Victorious, pa≈ø≈øed uncontrouled to the Gates of Abaville, and St. Valary; but they were, for want of guides to direct them, un-a-wars Entangled with the River Some on the one ≈øide, and the French Army on the other, which con≈øi≈øted of 100000 men; and the place where he was, promi≈øed
